dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObjects.title: Biology
dataObjects.description: Main channel of the Mananara du Nord has clear water with low turbidity and with bottom consisting of either sand or rock/cobble, lightly overlain with leaf litter in quieter stretches of the river; species is strictly nocturnal; onset of reproduction appears to coincide with end of dry season and onset of rains; indications of parental care; diet consists of aquatic insects and small freshwater shrimp (Ref. 75790).
dataObjects.references: Ng, H.H., J.S. Sparks and P.V. Loiselle 2008 A new species of catfish of the genus Gogo from the Northeastern Madagascar (Siluriformes: Anchariidae). Copeia 2008(2):395-400. (Ref. 75790)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObjects.description: Diagnosed from other species of the genus Gogo by possessing a longer snout, 54.8-56.4% HL (vs. 47.1-54.3) and faintly mottled dark gray coloration (vs. uniform brown, highly mottled dark gray and cream, or mottled brownish gray).  Distinguished further from Gogo ornatus in having a larger eye in specimens  >11.0 cm SL, diameter 13.0-14.3% HL (vs. 9.2-12.5), from Gogo brevibarbis in having unicuspid teeth (vs. bifurcate), and a smaller eye diameter 13.0-14.3% HL (vs. 19.5), and from Gogo arcuatus in having a narrower head, head width 17.8-18.9% SL (vs. 20.8-21.0); interorbital distance 28.9-30.5% HL (vs. 34.8-35.1), smaller eye diameter, 13.0-14.3% HL (vs. 17.7-18.6), shorter dorsal spine 17.7-20.6% SL (vs. 21.2-21.8) and pectoral spine 16.5-18.9% SL (vs. 19.9-20.2), and a straight (vs. concave) dorsoposterior margin of the dorsal fin (Ref. 75790).Description:  Dorsal fin with spinelet, spine and 7 rays; Anal fin with iv,7 or iv,8 rays;  Pectoral fin with stout spine, sharply pointed at tip, with 9 rays; Pelvic fin with i+5 rays (Ref. 75790).
dataObjects.references: Ng, H.H., J.S. Sparks and P.V. Loiselle 2008 A new species of catfish of the genus Gogo from the Northeastern Madagascar (Siluriformes: Anchariidae). Copeia 2008(2):395-400. (Ref. 75790)

dataObjects.subject: http://www.eol.org/voc/table_of_contents#Wikipedia
dataObjects.title: Gogo atratus
dataObjects.bibliographicCitation: "Gogo atratus." Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. 8 Mar 2013, 19:04 UTC. 21 Jul 2014 <http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Gogo_atratus&oldid=617339876>.
dataObjects.description:
Gogo atratus is a species of catfish of the family Anchariidae endemic to Madagascar where it is found in the Mananara du Nord River drainage in northeastern Madagascar.[1] It grows to a length of 17.1 cm.

G. atratus is strictly nocturnal. It reproduces at the end of the dry season and at the onset of the rainy season. The size of the eggs suggests that this species exhibits parental care, though this is unproven. G. atratus feed on aquatic insects and small freshwater shrimp.[1]

References[edit]

  • Froese, Rainer and Pauly, Daniel, eds. (2011). "Gogo atratus" in FishBase. December 2011 version.
  1. ^ a b Ng, Heok Hee; Sparks, John S.; Loiselle, Paul V. (2008). "A New Species of Catfish of the Genus Gogo from Northeastern Madagascar (Siluriformes: Anchariidae)". Copeia 2 (2): 395–400. doi:10.1643/CI-07-121.
